1.text: I reached an agreement with my eyes, that I would not so much as think about a virgin.

2.text: For what portion should God from above hold for me, and what inheritance should the Almighty from on high keep?

3.text: Is not destruction held for the wicked and repudiation kept for those who work injustice?

4.text: Does he not examine my ways and number all my steps?

5.text: If I have walked in vanity, or if my foot has hurried towards deceitfulness,

6.text: let him weigh me in a just balance, and let God know my simplicity.

7.text: If my steps have turned aside from the way, or if my heart has followed my eyes, or if a blemish has clung to my hands,

8.text: then may I sow, and let another consume, and let my offspring be eradicated.

9.text: If my heart has been deceived over a woman, or if I have waited in ambush at my friend’s door,

10.text: then let my wife be the harlot of another, and let other men lean over her.

11.text: For this is a crime and a very great injustice.

12.text: It is a fire devouring all the way to perdition, and it roots out all that springs forth.

13.text: If I have despised being subject to judgment with my servant or my maid, when they had any complaint against me,

14.text: then what will I do when God rises to judge, and, when he inquires, how will I respond to him?

15.text: Is not he who created me in the womb, also he who labored to make him? And did not one and the same form me in the womb?

16.text: If I have denied the poor what they wanted and have made the eyes of the widow wait;

17.text: if I have eaten my morsel of food alone, while orphans have not eaten from it;

18.text: (for from my infancy mercy grew with me, and it came out with me from my mother’s womb;)

19.text: if I have looked down on him who was perishing because he had no clothing and the poor without any covering,

20.text: if his sides have not blessed me, and if he were not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;

21.text: if I have lifted up my hand over an orphan, even when it might seem to me that I the advantage over him at the gate;

22.text: then may my shoulder fall from its joint, and may my arm, with all its bones, be broken.

23.text: For I have always feared God, like waves flowing over me, whose weight I was unable to bear.

24.text: If I have considered gold to be my strength, or if I have called purified gold ‘my Trust;’

25.text: if I have rejoiced over my great success, and over the many things my hand has obtained;

26.text: if I gazed upon the sun when it shined and the moon advancing brightly,

27.text: so that my heart rejoiced in secret and I kissed my hand with my mouth,

28.text: which is a very great iniquity and a denial against the most high God;

29.text: if I have been glad at the ruin of him who hated me and have exulted that evil found him,

30.text: for I have not been given my throat to sin by asking for a curse on his soul;

31.text: if the men around my tabernacle have not said: “He might give us some of his food, so that we will be filled,”

32.text: for the foreigner did not remain at the door, my door was open to the traveler;

33.text: if, as man does, I have hidden my sin and have concealed my iniquity in my bosom;

34.text: if I became frightened by an excessive crowd, and the disrespect of close relatives alarmed me, so that I would much rather have remained silent or have gone out the door;

35.text: then, would he grant me a hearing, so that the Almighty would listen to my desire, and he who judges would himself write a book,

36.text: which I would then carry on my shoulder and wrap around me like a crown?

37.text: With each of my steps, I would pronounce and offer it, as if to a prince.

38.text: So, if my land cries out against me, and if its furrows weep with it,

39.text: if I have used its fruits for nothing but money and have afflicted the souls of its tillers,

40.text: then, may thistles spring forth for me instead of grain, and thorns instead of barley. (This ended the words of Job.)
